Marlien

Marlien is a magical Creation within the Great Beyond which was constructed by the Dead Gods.

Names

Marlien is known by many names:

  • Marlien - from the parable of Solen and Marlien in the Arthalean religion Solenist Academia, where it is the name of the creator, or sleeping godess who dreams creation.

Topography

Marlien is a poly-dimensional Creation whose structure can be divided into three, discrete Planes: the Astral, Ethereal, and Material. In common parlance the Immaterial is refered to as a 'higher' plane, but it is more appropriate to describe the Material as the surface, then move deeper into the Ethereal, and then deeper still into the Astral, whose depths extend into a vast, unknown void. Within the Material, Marlien is further divided into sub-Planes, each having disparate topographies with some overlap, intersection, and imitation. These sub-Planes are often manifestations of will expressed from greater depths, a product of residual will from activities long ago, or merely the design of the Dead Gods. The primary, most balanced and diverse, of these planes is named The Prime Material Plane.

Planar Physics

Physical bodies in Marlien gravitate strongly towards the Material plane, and it is there where all unclaimed anicca finds itself at rest, in the shapeless plane named Solitude. atman typically reside in the Astral, even when bound to physical vessels at other depths, and are usually only drawn into the Material forcefully, or in trying to maintain a strong connection with a dying vessel. Similarly, physical bodies may only be drawn from, and held outside of the Material by the strong and sustained will of an atman; such is true even for the entities who reside physically, and permanently at or beyond the Astral plane, which is why these are predominantly beings of great power and intellect.

physical vessel-bound atman are typically protected from the aggressions of other atman, even if they reside at a different depth, but this protection wanes as they move further apart. In the Astral plane reside a multitude of unpleasant entities - often unbound hungers too weak to press down into the Material plane - which would otherwise consume the souls of living men, but must instead wait until these souls are set free, or are fool enough to bring their vessels nearer.

Planar Travel

Moving through the depths of Marlien is simple enough - it simply takes a strong enough will to draw a soul up to the Material plane, or a physical body down into the Astral. Though some of the Material sub-Planes overlap, intersect, or border one-another, allowing for Plane Gates, others are only connected by the web-ways of the Ethereal plane, and others still by only the Astral plane. The Halls of the Charon, for example, are only connected to other sub-planes via the astral plane, save for the The Everstair, which exists within them.

Astral Projection

Astral Projection is the practice of willing one's own perception into the perspective of the atman instead of the physical vessel. With practice, a capable entity might learn to move its atman separately from its physical vessel, and see through the depths to the Ethereal, or Material from that perspective - even seeing into other planes, since the Astral and Ethereal planes have no such barriers as the Material.

Intersection

At points where two sub-planes intersect, there planar travel is most trivial. Often there is some obscure route or movement which must be followed in order to cross the intersection, but no other exertion or application of

Plane Shift

Plane shifting is the simplest, but perhaps most dangerous method of planar travel. It involves simply lowering the physical vessel into either the Ethereal or Astral as required, moving it to the vicinity of the desired sub-plane, and then releasing it back into the Material.

Because it is not always clear which parts of the Ethereal or Astral planes correspond to which parts of the Material planes, and there are certain routes in the Ethereal plane which are not connected, it can be difficult to tell, while plane shifting, how to reach the desired sub-plane. This is especially true for undisciplined travellers foolhardy enough to attempt a plane shift, who may not even be able to see out of the depths, and may simply embed themselves in a wall, or other unpleasant circumstance.

Further danger arises from the vessel's greater proximity to the immaterial, where a great many fledgling hungers gather about any concentration of other atman, and will relish the opportunity to strike at a vessel which they ordinarily could not reach.

Plane Gate

Currents of mana flow between the sub-planes which are in direct contact, frequently opening up fissures between worlds. Microscopic fissures opened by these currents are frequent, and allow small, nimble creatures with a sense for them to easily pop from world to world, while larger fissures are rarer, and equally unpredictable. It is important to understand that the endpoints of these fissures usually vary greatly in position, even in overlapping sub-planes.

The simplest application of these fissures is to predict their location and magnitude, and simply move with the current. Alternatively, a sustained, or even permanent plane gate can be created by the application of additional mana to a fissure. While it is technically possible to create such a fissure artificially, it is neither economical, or simple to accomplish.

Supplanting

Supplanting is a technique derived from the creation of plane gates, and utilised by the Kyton flesh_city Nustalem in its efforts to move its enormous body from shadow to The Prime Material Plane. Instead of applying additional mana to simply sustain a plane gate, supplanting uses mana to move the plane gate, expand it, and wrap it around an object. This movement occurs at both sides of the fissure, and so whatever resides on each side swaps location. This allows incredibly large, or immobile objects to be moved between sub-planes, with the risk being that it is slow, and may cause great harm if interrupted.

The Circle of Life

The Charon consider themselves wardens of the atman in Marlien, and arbiters of life and death. They ferry the souls of the dead across the Astral to be held in The Everstair until they are needed for another vessel.

Spectres

When a soul is particularly invested in its vessel, its struggle to hold on the that body at the point of its ultimate demise might draw it up into the Material plane, where it exerts a great deal of will to remain. The presence of an unbound An unbound atman in the Material plane naturally attracts motes of unclaimed anicca, manifesting as a visible specter, though it may suppress this attraction through instinct or intellect. Specters may also arise when the atman of a dead vessel slips through the net, and no Charon awaits to ferry it away.
